headline: The U.S. tax loophole that made Shein and Temu rich is changing. What will happen to the brands now? | CBC News
context: For years, Shein and Temu used a U.S. tax loophole to keep their costs low and send items to the country ultra-quickly.

annotations.paragraph: U.S. President Donald Trump signed an executive order on April 2 to end the de minimis exemption — a rule that allows small packages worth less than $800 US to enter the U.S. tax free — for packages from China and Hong Kong, effective Friday.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a key fact about the change in the tax rule affecting Shein and Temu.

annotations.paragraph: The de minimis rule exists to prevent customs agents from spending too much time processing small packages that don't yield much money for the government in import taxes. But now, the Trump administration is reversing the rule for imports from China, saying the exemption has allowed illegal drugs to come into the country.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers context on the purpose of the de minimis rule and the reason for its reversal.

annotations.paragraph: Companies like Shein and Temu, both of which were founded in China, have used the rule to their advantage, shipping orders to the U.S. as individual packages rather than bringing shipping crates full of items in, storing them in warehouses and distributing to consumers from there, as most retailers do.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains how Shein and Temu utilized the loophole, directly relating to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: The exemption is a big part of what helped keep Shein and Temu's prices so low, according to Samuel Roscoe, a lecturer in supply chain and operations management at the University of British Columbia's business school.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides expert commentary on the impact of the exemption on Shein and Temu's pricing.

annotations.paragraph: WATCH | Why a U.S. tax move aimed at China could punish Canadians and Americans:
annotations.reason: This is a prompt to watch a video, not a paragraph contributing to the article's narrative.

annotations.paragraph: Why a U.S. tax move aimed at China could punish Canadians and Americans
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a headline and does not provide new information or context.
This is a timestamp and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: "I would expect them to take a significant hit, but still trying to compete in the United States," Roscoe said.
annotations.reason: This quote provides direct commentary on the impact of the tax change on the companies.

annotations.paragraph: But while price increases, supply chain factors and a possible slowing of packages at the border will be obstacles, experts say the hits won't take out the companies completely, nor the fast fashion model they accelerated.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers expert analysis on the potential impact of the tax change on the companies.

annotations.paragraph: As of Friday, small packages under $800 US in value entering the U.S. from China will be subject to duties of 120 per cent, or a $100 flat rate fee. The flat rate is set to rise to $200 as of June 1.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the new tax changes affecting the companies.

annotations.paragraph: Cost of Living9:46How Shein took over the world — one $2 shirt at a time
annotations.reason: This is a podcast title and does not contribute new information to the article.

annotations.paragraph: As a whole, Kozlowski says tariffs won't disrupt fast fashion because they don't address the root cause — our desire for ultra-cheap stuff.
annotations.reason: This provides commentary on the impact of tariffs on fast fashion, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: "We're still going to have a culture of consumption," Kozlowski said. "It doesn't break that addiction."
annotations.reason: This quote supports the previous statement about consumer culture, adding depth to the discussion.

annotations.paragraph: She says any real solutions will have to start there — as does Roscoe.
annotations.reason: This is a vague statement without specific information or context.

annotations.paragraph: Roscoe says Shein and Temu came along and supercharged the fast fashion model that companies like Zara started in the late '90s. Whereas a fast fashion garment used to take months to go from a concept to a real product, Shein in particular can turn around a new item in as little as 25 days, making the churn of the clothing industry even more rapid than in the past.
annotations.reason: This provides specific information about Shein and Temu's business model and its impact on the industry.

annotations.paragraph: Roscoe says slowing this pace would require efforts such as government legislation against wasteful and exploitative processes, as well as consumer boycotts of brands that take part in those practices.
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses potential actions unrelated to the specific tax loophole change affecting Shein and Temu.
